data.title: Hash function for Vector3 does not perform well
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Windows 10 / Godot 2.0.3

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

I have some performance issues with `Vector3` used as a key in a dictionary (approx. 9k items & 50k tests). The execution gets 3 times faster if `str(vec3)` is used instead.

I was able to track the issue down to three calls of `hash_djb2_one_float()` function in [hashfuncs.h](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/master/core/hashfuncs.h#L72) but I cannot see any problem there. Maybe this particular hash function results in many collisions for my data (uniform non-cubic 3D grid).

data.title: Android: Duplicate meshes do not work
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.03 stable - Win x64 - Android 5.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The sample code loads a scene containing a cube and duplicates the `Mesh` from its `MeshInstance` onto two additional `MeshInstances` which initially have no mesh attached.

Running from the editor or exporting to Windows works as three cubes can be seen:
![desktop](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11797174/15804880/78872262-2b18-11e6-8016-12ea85d8a6f5.png)

Exporting and running on Android doesn't work as only the original cube is displayed:
![android](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11797174/15804883/86e1f134-2b18-11e6-95f6-f23263a26ae7.png)

**Steps to reproduce:**
In GDScript call `MeshInstance.set_mesh()` to set a duplicate of the mesh got from another via `MeshInstance.get_mesh().duplicate()`.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-WnZEtQk02PSmRkYXo0cFJDdGc/view?usp=sharing

data.title: Add joystick vibration support on Linux
data.body:
Related to #5013 
This pull request adds joystick vibration support on Linux.
Here is the cross platform API:
- `Input.start_joy_vibration(device, weak_magnitude, strong_magnitude)` to start the joystick vibration
- `Input.stop_joy_vibration(device)` to stop the vibration
- `Input.get_joy_vibration(device)` to get the current strength of the vibration

**TODO**:
- Add support for Windows and OS X (unfortunately I don't know the API for these platforms, hopefully someone could add support after this PR is merged)
- Update the joystick demo (I will do that myself when this PR is merged)

I don't know much about Godot's codebase, so don't hesitate to tell me if I did something wrong :)

data.title: On Windows at least building with a -j > 1 scons parameter fails with a file not found even though the file exists
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Windows 10 Pro 64-bit, Godot source 64-bit build (tested with master branch)

Visual Studio 2015 Community, Windows 10 SDK Kit 10586.

Python 2.7.11, Scons 2.5.0, and Pywin32 220 all these tools are 32-bit.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

When I issue the command:

scons platform=windows target=release_debug -jx

Where "x" is a number > 1 then the build process will eventually give a file not found error.  Going to where it says the file is not found it is present.  Specifying -j1 on the build line works fine.

**Steps to reproduce:**

scons platform=windows target=release_debug -j2

data.title: Need help completing editor customizable shortcuts!
data.body:
Editor shortcuts can now be customized, and there are a new few tools for this, specially the ShortCut resource.

Most of editor_node.cpp has been converted, but the rest of the editor remains. Here's the global functions that can be used:

`ED_SHORTCUT(const String& p_path,const String& p_name,uint32_t p_keycode=0);`

This defines a new shortcut, which must contain a section/identifier path, a translatable name and a keyboard shortcut. Returns a shortcut object which can be added to a button or to a menu. An example of this from editor_node.cpp:

```
`p->add_shortcut(ED_SHORTCUT("editor/save_scene_as",TTR("Save Scene As.."),KEY_MASK_SHIFT+KEY_MASK_CMD+KEY_S),FILE_SAVE_AS_SCENE);
```

`

Many times, the menus, buttons, etc. are created on the fly, so call this function again on a constructor or at some place where initialization occurs, this way it can always appear in editor settings dialog. Just call it and ignore the return, as it will be cached for next time you call it.
`
ED_SHORTCUT("editor/save_scene_as",TTR("Save Scene As.."),KEY_MASK_SHIFT+KEY_MASK_CMD+KEY_S)
`
Optionally and for simplicity you can simply get the shortcut, but it must have defined as above!

```
Ref<ShortCut> ED_GET_SHORTCUT(const String& p_path);

usded like:

somebutton->set_shortcut( ED_GET_SHORTCUT("editor/save_scene_as") );
```

In many places, checking for a shortcut is done manually from an unhandled input callback. Generally this is done with a switch(), so it will have to be changed to a sequence of ifs(). In such cases simply define the shortcut as in the code (two samples above ^), then check manually against an InputEvent: 

```
if ( ED_IS_SHORTCUT("editor/save_scene_as") ) {
...
}
```

I think this is all! Good luck :)

Added InputMap.get_actions()

Adds `InputMap.get_actions()` which lists all actions in the InputMap. Resolves #5033 

However I think the `InputMap.get_action_list(var action)` is misleading and should be renamed to something like `InputMap.action_get_events(var action)`, however thats maybe for another PR.

data.title: Right click->Quit on the godot icon will close the application on OSX
data.body: Also fixed get_window_position that missed a return on OSX.

data.title: Methods for supporting advanced and deterministic screen capture
data.body:
This PR simply adds a couple of methods to aid in doing in some things with screen capturing which wasn't previously possible which are fairly self-contained. The first is a renderer method for disabling buffer swapping. By turning this off, the game can retain what it last rendered while still rendering something else internally. With this, you could make it so the properties of the screenshot change without it being visible to the player. In my specific case, I use it for an ingame camera phone which has an overlay which gets removed during the screenshot phase. Once the screenshot has been successfully processed, you can then turn swap buffering back on.

The other method relates to the feeling that in the demo project, where the script simply waits two frames before getting the screen capture. Since capturing screenshots is multi-threaded, this method is not 'truly' deterministic, since although it's unlikely, it's theoretically possible that a screenshot could take longer to process. As such, I've added a simple method to check whether any screenshots are still pending, and the idea is you would continually loop and check if the screenshot has finished processing, at which point you can do something with it. You may also prefer to pause the tree, which would allow a more controlled way of handling screenshots while still being able to take advantage of multi-threading to avoid the problem of the application stalling.

data.title: A proper mean to get the list of InputMap actions
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Official 2.0.3stable win64

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I've found no clean way to iterate through InputMap actions, and i've found no way to get the list of actions names.

If I do something like this, this ends up with an error.

```
    var index = 1 # <------ index 0 seems unavailable
    var action = InputMap.get_action_from_id(index)
    while action != "":
        print(action)
        index+=1
        action = InputMap.get_action_from_id(index)
```

**ERROR:** `InputMap::get_action_from_id: Condition ' !input_id_map.has(p_id) ' is true. returned: StringName()`
`At: core\input_map.cpp:74`

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Physics2D: Rename default_density to default_linear_damp
[TRACKER] Removal of the editor's debugging prints
data.body:
The Godot editor currently has many debugging prints that don't serve real purposes to users, such as:
- [x] "found bug?"
- [x] "LANG IS (language code)"
- [x] "TESTING (language code)"
- [x] "ok translation"
- [x] "DPI MODE: (something)"
- [x] "VBoxContainer: 136,100"
- [x] "bind toptions"
- [x] "settings changed"
- [x] "********\* listening on port 6007"
- [x] "OK! 23"
- [x] "has connection!"
- [x] "pre-removing print handler..."
- [x] "removing print handler..."
- [x] "found"
- [x] "CLOSING CONNECTION"
- [x] "performing reparent"
- [x] "returned: 19840, waiting for: 19840"
- [x] "parent function"
- [x] "Built in type constant"

Some of those messages will even be printed in exported projects. I suggest that those messages are hidden from `release` and `release_debug` builds at least.

_Once the message has been removed, the checkbox can be checked next to it._

data.title: Exposing more physics constants to project settings
data.body:
Follow-up on #505.

@marynate had proposed to expose physics parameters like https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/5be9ff7/scene/resources/world_2d.cpp#L381 and https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/a75f896/servers/physics/space_sw.cpp#L728 to the project settings for fine-tuning by the users.

I could PR @marynate's changes again but I see other constants that might be worth exposing, and overall I have too little experience with the physics engine to say if those changes would be sensible.

So, feedback appreciated :)

data.title: Typing only `print` in the script editor spams the console with "found bug?"
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.0.3 and master, Mageia 6 x86_64.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When starting to type `print` or `print(` in the text editor, the code parser properly notifies the user that the the syntax is wrong.
But the console gets spammed with messages that suggest that the parser is failing to understand the situation:

```
found bug?
No completion
found bug?
found bug?
hint: void print( |var what|, var ... )
found bug?
```

**Steps to reproduce:**
Start typing `print` in any GDScript file in the editor.

data.title: Add Array.find_last() and Array.count()
data.body: Added Array.find_last(var) and Array.count(var), with documentation. I think this is a nice feature to have available in engine/in gdscript. `find_last(var)` is inspired by `String.find_last(var)` for consistency.  See #5020.

data.title: find() only returns single index in array with duplicates.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 16.04 Godot v2 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
test_arr["test0","test1","test2","test2"]
using find on this array with return only index 2 instead while ignoring 3 three even though it also has the same value. Is there a way to have it return multiple indexes that share the same value?

Not sure if was intentional or not just mainly curious about the behavior.

**Steps to reproduce:**

```
var test_arr = ["test0","test1","test2","test2"]
for i in range(test_arr.size()):
    print("1st loop")
    print(test_arr[i])
    for j in range(test_arr.size()):
        print("2nd loop")
        print(test_arr[j])
        print(test_arr.find("test2"))
```

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Editor plugin crashes when removed the "tool" keyword
data.body:
Removing the `tool` keyword from a plugin script crashes the editor.

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create a new project.
- Create a folder called `addons` inside the project.
- Add a custom plugin to the `addons` folder. You can grab one [from the demos](https://github.com/godotengine/godot-demo-projects/tree/master/plugins).
- Enable the plugin in Project Settings and then disable it.
- Open the plugin main script, remove the `tool` keyword and save the script.
- Watch the Editor crashing.

data.title: It's almost impossible to deselect text in editor help
data.body:
If you select a text in editor help, the selection doesn't go away if you click somewhere else (as it is expected).

You might be able to deselect by dragging in an empty area between methods, but that's not easy.

data.title: Editor help needs a better easier-to-read layout
data.body:
Currently the editor help is hard to read. You can't tell in a glance what is a method's signature and what is its description.

![godot windows opt tools 64_2016-06-03_12-56-35](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5599796/15784936/28b811f8-298b-11e6-9304-507eb1a74f4c.png)
- The font is also too big, especially when contrasted with the monospaced font used in the code examples.
- The font for method signature should be a bit bigger.
- The space between paragraphs is too big, while the space between methods could be bigger.
- The methods' names don't stand out. So it's hard to tell to which method this description is about. A color would go miles in this way, so if method names were e.g. yellow, it'd be much more visible (check the bottom of the previous image, which shows a link to a function in yellow).
- Sometimes the text gets too close of the right border. There should be a right margin and also a greater left margin. ![godot windows opt tools 64_2016-06-03_13-02-56](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5599796/15785333/2557c9a2-298d-11e6-9b09-23e93642c597.png)
- New lines in `classes.xml` should not make paragraphs. It's usually hard to edit long lines, so double new lines should make paragraphs instead. Otherwise we get something like this: ![godot windows opt tools 64_2016-06-03_12-48-11](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5599796/15785389/542f700e-298d-11e6-9437-2be883b4819c.png)
